awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Operating High Purity Germanium Detectors in Liquid Scintillator
awd_abstract_narration:
Neutrinos are subatomic particles abundantly produced in Nature. It has been challenging to investigate the intrinsic properties of the ghostly neutrinos, because they can pass through instruments and materials with barely any interactions. Thanks to advancements of technology as well as long-term commitment of the science community, recent breakthroughs have revealed critical yet unexpected properties of neutrinos, such as the fact that neutrinos have non-zero masses. New knowledge on neutrinos can probe fundamental symmetries in Nature and could shed light on the key mystery of matter-over-antimatter excess in the universe. Extrasolar neutrinos are also one of the messengers carrying information about the universe that can lead us to a more complete picture of the universe. This proposal aims at developing techniques that could facilitate experiments to deepen our understanding of neutrinos, including probing the origin of non-zero neutrino masses. It will also advance the collaboration between the University of South Dakota (USD) and Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) in new directions. The transformative new expertise gained by the USD group will enhance the group's research capability in Underground Science and Engineering, one of the high value research areas and assets aligned with target industry sectors for South Dakota.

The PI at USD plans to visit LANL to develop active veto techniques employing liquid argon (LAr), intended for the proposed Large Enriched Germanium Experiment for Neutrinoless double-beta Decay (LEGEND) project. Both the home and host groups are LEGEND collaborators. The LEGEND collaboration aims to develop a phased, Ge-76 based neutrinoless double-beta decay (NLDBD) experimental program with discovery potential at a half-life beyond 10e28 years. LEGEND will operate up to one tonne of high-purity germanium detectors inside a large volume of LAr. The LAr shield serves as an active veto that is powerful in eliminating a wide range of backgrounds for NLDBD. Specifically, the PI and trainees will collaborate with LANL researchers to convert an existing cryostat at LANL into a LAr test stand with purification capability and light collection instrumentation. We will directly immerse and operate high-purity germanium detectors inside liquid argon. Through this collaborative research between USD and LANL, we can evaluate the overall performance of the integrated system and improve our understanding of the background rejection performance of a LAr active veto. In addition to advancing the preparation for the LEGEND project, this Research Fellowship will arm the PI with expertise on liquid scintillator technologies and enable the PI to sustain his career in experimental neutrino physics in the long-term. A combination of hardware infrastructure and technical expertise at LANL is essential to carry out the proposed activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Liquid Argon (LAr) is a type of scintillator, which will emit light when there is energy deposition within. LAr techniques have been widely used in cutting-edge particle and nuclear experiments that are aimed at understanding different properties of neutrinos, an abundant but elusive elementary particle, and/or at detecting dark matter, which is predicted to exist only based on astronomical and cosmological observations. For example, the Large Enriched Germanium Experiment for Neutrinoless double-beta Decay (LEGEND) project will utilize a LAr veto detector to achieve great improvements in background suppression, which is critical for the project to capture its promising potential to search for the neutrinoless double-beta decay, a hypothetical lepton-number-violating process that may address the origin of mysterious neutrino mass and shed light on why there are more matter than antimatter in the Universe.

 

Supported by this fellowship, a team of researchers from the University of South Dakota (USD) made multiple trips in 2021 and 2022 to New Mexico to work with collaborators from Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) and the University of New Mexico (UNM) to upgrade a 100-liter LAr test stand on the UNM campus. The COVID-19 pandemic has caused significant delays in the project and has negatively impacted on the overall project progress. By the end of this project, about half of the original grant was spent. The technical research activities focused on upgrading the light collection instrumentation, along with the data acquisition system and slow control system. Key parameters of the test stand now can be remotely monitored and a significant fraction of the vacuum valves were replaced with remotely-controlled parts. The old Photomultiplier tube (PMT) was replaced by a new Hamamatsu PMT that is more suitable for liquid Xenon light readout, which is ideal for the study of Xenon-doping of LAr. Studies of the Hamamatsu Generation-4 Silicon PhotoMultipliers (SiPMs) were carried out under different conditions. As the main light collection detectors with sensitivity at both liquid Argon and Xenon light wavelengths, a dozen of these SiPMs are deployed inside the system with new holders, feedthrough flanges, cables, and connectors. These upgrades will allow better study of LAr light yields, including changes due to xenon-doping into LAr. As USD, UNM, and LANL are participating institutions of the LEGEND collaboration, the collective activities by the USD team and collaborators produce valuable experience with the LAr technology for the LEGEND collaboration and help build a foundation for future research to be carried out with this LAr test stand. Our collaborators have received funding to continue research activities with this upgraded LAr test stand. 


Graduate student and postdoc trainees were provided opportunities to participate in this project and received significant training on a range of hardware and software skills, particularly for the technology of Silicon Photomultipliers. Their communication and collaborative skills were also improved. The graduate student trainee continues to make contributions to the LEGEND project and the postdoc trainee now works for a semiconductor manufacturing company. This is a positive result on human resource development in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics for the society.
